author: Ryan Wilson
title: Saints coach Joe Vitt tears Achilles, breaks wrist after chasing car thieves
text:
Joe Vitt, who has been coaching in the NFL since 1979, is known for his toughness. And that extends beyond the football field. The Saints ' linebackers coach chased two people who were trying to steal his car Saturday morning and ended up tearing his Achilles tendon and breaking his wrist in the process, a team spokesman told ESPN.com .
But because Joe Vitt is Joe Vitt, he didn't miss a day of work.
More details of the thwarted crime:
The incident occurred shortly before 4 a.m. on Saturday, according to Jefferson Parish Sheriff's Office spokesman Col. John Fortunato. Vitt was walking through his kitchen when he noticed a shadow running across his front lawn. When he went outside to investigate, he noticed a white female with blonde hair wearing khaki shorts and gloves attempting to enter a neighbor's vehicle. Vitt then looked toward his own car and saw a white male inside the vehicle.

When they saw Vitt, they took off running, according to Fortunato. Vitt pursued them on foot for a short distance before tripping and causing injuries that required a trip to the hospital. The suspects remain at large. Vitt began his coaching career with the Colts and has been with the Saints since 2006. He served as interim coach in New Orleans during the 2012 season when coach Sean Payton was suspended for his role in the bounty scandal. When not coaching NFL players, Joe Vitt is also a crime fighter. (USATSI) Topics: Ryan Wilson , New Orleans Saints , NFL
